Title: Remote Development with JetBrains Rider
Description: JetBrains provides access to Remote Development Beta. The tool works by locally running a thin client and connecting to the IDE backend which gives a fully functional user interface. It can be handled by JetBrains Rider or JetBrains Gateway. The workflow of the tool is smooth as editing is done locally and the JetBrains client synchronises changes with the backend.

Title: PgBouncer is useful, important, and fraught with peril
Description:
To start, I want to say that Iâ€™m appreciative that PgBouncer exists and the work its open source maintainers put into it. I also love working with PostgreSQL, and Iâ€™m thankful for the incredible amount of work and improvements that go into it as well.
I also think community and industry enthusiasm around Postgres is at an all time high. There are more managed hosting options than ever (Crunchy Data, Render, Fly.

Title: Format JSON in Vim with jq
Description:
jq is a very powerful command-line tool designed to manipulate JSON data. One of its great features is that it automatically formats JSON output for better readability:
$ echo '{"is_jq_awesome": true}' | jq { "is_jq_awesome": true } But in Vim? Can we utilize this inside of Vim? Of course!
In Vim, thereâ€™s a feature called filter commands that enables us to use external applications to modify our buffers. Filter commands take a range, which is a set of contiguous lines, and a command that processes these lines.

Title: touchHLE in depth, part 1: a day in the life of a function call
Description: This is the first in what will hopefully be a series of technical write-ups of various aspects of touchHLE, a high-level emulator for iPhone OS applications. (See also: the touchHLE announcement blog post from two months ago.) These write-ups will be aimed at an audience familiar with systems programming, but which isn't necessarily familiar with emulator development, ARMv6 assembly, Rust, Objective-C, and so on.

Title: Recipes For Product Failure: Obsess Over Competitors
Description: If product management was ever perfected and applied evenly to every single company and industry, we'd likely _swim_ in products that solve all our problems. Unfortunately, good product management is unevenly distributed and often takes on patterns and practices that are very far from optimal.
